So can you talk a little bit about – the capital markets are telling you something, but does that play into your decision whether to keep the dividend, does it not? Are you waiting to see what kind of unemployment rates we're sitting on in six months before you make a more longer-term decision? Maybe just talk through the thought process and also just what the Board has been discussing since your update in December.

Sure, Scott. What I would say is that the results that we got in the quarter were what we thought we would get when we had the December meeting. The cash flow was actually stronger, so our cash position is actually improved today versus even where we were in December. The overall capital inside the company, cash inside the company, is almost $50 billion. Our Industrial cash flow for the quarter was $5.3 billion, so we feel good about the liquidity and the cash plan inside the company.

So then the question is, how do you use that capital and how do you use that cash? We're investing in the future, so we're not starving the businesses. We're reinvesting back into the long-term growth of the company. And it has just been our feeling that the dividend is a good return to investors in this moment of uncertainty, but we're not straining in order to pay it. In other words, we've got lots of cash, and lots of free cash flow, and lots of capital inside the company. And so it has just been the judgment that this has been the most investor-friendly use of this capital.
Okay, good explanation. Thanks, guys.
Thanks, Scott.
And your next question comes from the line of Jason Feldman with UBS.
Good morning.
Hi, Jason.

So if I'm reading the slides right, you're showing that the reserves you're expecting to increase about $2 billion into '09, but provisions are only going up about 2.5 billion. So am I missing something? Are you basically only expecting write-offs to increase 5, $600 million next year?
The provisions include the write-offs and reserves.
Understood. So if the provision is up 2.5?

Yes, write-offs were up $2 billion this year. We really had a massive acceleration of write-offs, even at – with the provision up three billion, with the write-offs we're up two billion. I think you're seeing those at a run rate that's more reflective, certainly on the consumer side, than they're probably going to accelerate, I would say, on the commercial side, yes.
Okay, so you expect a deceleration in the rate of growth of the write-offs?
On the consumer side.
Okay, okay. Thank you very much.
Yes.
And your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa with J.P. Morgan.
Good morning, Steve.

Hi, good morning. Just a question on the reserves, I noticed that you didn't really change the mix much of consumer and commercial, and it's hard to read it on the bar chart. Commercial looks actually – and this is on the credit losses – looks actually flat relative to '08. Looking at some of the loss statistics and what you guys have said about the corporate credit cycle, is that conservative enough, or does most – does that increase again in 2010? Just, if you could just talk about the dynamics around the commercial side, because it looks like once again, most of the provisioning is coming from consumer.

The total allowance was up about $400 million from the third quarter in the commercial business. It was up $600 million year over year, so we're stepping into the commercial allowance as well. I think the difference is that we're senior secured and you're going to see a slower loss cycle on the commercial side. On the consumer side, obviously we're already seeing it, on the delinquencies in the U.S. books specifically. I think the mortgage book has a slower and more delayed loss response. But yes, we've stepped up on the commercial side based on broad pressure in the economy, higher delinquencies, and higher non-earnings.
But am I right that you're saying that basically the '09 rate is about in line with '08 because you stepped up so much in the fourth quarter I guess is what you're saying?
I think both are going to be up in 2009, Steve. Maybe the bar chart doesn't show it. I'll have to get you some better numbers on it, but both are clearly going to be up in 2009.
Okay. And then as far as the – sorry.
When you take the provision up to $10 billion, you're going to see three-quarters of that's in the consumer side, the increase, and probably a quarter in the commercial side.
Right. Okay.

Look, I think from the December 2 meeting, we've taken the loss provisions up $1 billion in '10. And I think stepped into some of it in the fourth quarter and taking the estimates up for next year and then the $5 billion walk haven't changed the dynamic around losses. So I think we feel like we've been pretty conservative. I don't think there is any reason not to be conservative as we estimate these losses. We're in the credit cycle. We've been in this business for a long time. And we underwrite differently than the banks; we're senior secured. But look, I think we've done a lot to step into a very tough environment.
Steve, I just looked at the bar chart. The bar chart was – the bars haven't been updated for the increase of the number at the top of the bar, so I apologize for that.
Okay. So that's the – so commercial is actually higher than what that bar chart shows?
Right, the bar chart is related to the December 2. We didn't change the bar in there. We just updated the number for the total losses. Sorry about that.
Got you, I thought my ruler was wrong for a second. When you look at the mark-to-market, you said I think this year how much did you have in mark-to-market, 1.6 billion I think you said?
On a pre-tax basis, yes.
1.6 billion. So that applies to everything basically other than your receivables base, so like 200 billion in assets, I guess. Is that the number we should be thinking about?
It would be a lot less than that.
Okay.

I think the mark-to-market – some of the impairments are obviously on the 200 billion that's not financing receivables. But a lot of the impairments that we took this year were on public equity securities. We had a couple billion dollars that's down to about $1 billion I believe, the amount that is sitting there in that category. So we've had definitely a lot of marks that we've taken that have reduced the basis of a lot of the public securities that we had.

Right. And then one more question, and this goes back to cash flow. And I guess on the Industrial side, you guys have some pretty solid working capital targets to generate the cash. Is there anything – a lot of companies are pulling out all of the stops to conserve cash. Is there anything that you guys are doing? Maybe you could just talk about what you're doing on your payables maybe or at GE Capital, whether it's rebate programs to accelerate balance reductions at your customers. Anything there that would be – can you just talk about how you've changed those policies to really batten down the hatches here? I know all companies are doing that stuff. I'm just curious as to how you guys are going about that.

Sure. We've got an Operating Council, as Jeff said. The focus is on margins and on cash. When you look at cash, we've got specific targets for every single business around inventory. We're using Lean throughout the company to drive inventory down, to get our cycle times down. We're using the same techniques around our receivables. We're working diligently to reduce our past due receivables across the company, to change our terms where we've got too much extended terms versus the margin we get on the equipment. We do have a discount program with GE Capital where suppliers can get paid early by taking a discount that's got a good ROE on it. And we are working on a supply base to try and extend our payable terms by about four or five days. So every element of working capital is being intensely worked on here across this company.

And I think the thing on working capital that the environment change actually helps us on, as you know, we've had high single digit, double digit revenue growth in the Industrial business for the last three years. Now we're going into a tougher environment. We're not going to need as much working capital. And that's going to help us a lot from a cash flow perspective in 2009 in addition to all of the actions we're doing from the Operating Council.
What are normal payables terms, just at high levels?
About 55 – 60 days.
Okay, great. Thanks.

The point I'd make, just to amplify what Keith said is we've done a lot here to be able to control our own destiny. We've taken the cost out. We have for the last year been driving real cash programs. I think some of that showed up in the fourth quarter. We're just running the place with intensity. And I think the fact that we've got almost $50 billion of cash and liquidity and strong programs demonstrates that we've done the right actions to better weather this cycle.
And then just one more very quick one, how much of your backlog ships in 2009?
A little over half.
Yes, the chart in December, Steve, I think really shows...
About 26 billion of the 50 billion.
Yes.
Okay, great. Thanks a lot, guys.
Lauren, we're bumping against 10:00 here. Why don't we take just take one more question?
Your final question comes from the line of Terry Darling with Goldman Sachs.

Thanks, Keith, I'll try to be quick here. Coming back to the value gap discussion, you had mentioned you're expecting 2 billion of raw materials savings in '09 in your forecast. I'm wondering if you can give us the net number there, which would lead us to ask you about price assumption in that context.

Yes, we're going to expect to see a positive price in 2009. A lot of that obviously is already in the backlog, Terry. We haven't given out a number of what the net dollar amount is between the two. What we said in December and Jeff outlined, was that we expect margins to grow, and we had a number of tailwinds that were going to help us. We've got price in the backlog. We had – originally when we came into the fourth quarter of '08, businesses looking at about a little bit of inflation. We've been working with the sourcing teams to actually turn that into deflation. And we're talking about a big part of that direct material drop to be from deflation that we're going to get from the supply chain as we work through the year here and as the global economy slows and people are going to be really chasing the commodity supplies.
Also in terms of the shift here where profit starts to outperform revenue on the Industrial side, should we be expecting that shift to occur in the first half or more in the second half?

I don't have a breakout of that, Terry. I think we're going to have to work on that. I think you're going to see equipment versus services all year long turn into more of a services revenue growth versus equipment. I don't know exactly the pace by quarter.

Yes, what I would say, Terry, is that the service versus equipment will probably be flip-flopping in the first half of the year. The value gap I think is pretty solid right now, and the restructuring actions get feathered in as the year goes on. So you've got some that will happen in the first half and some that will happen in the second half is the way I would say it.

Okay. And then in terms of the additional restructuring, do you have a number we ought to be thinking about in terms of building into the – additional restructuring number we could talk about in terms of building into the numbers at this point?
We had this year about 1.5 billion after tax; and next year we're including in the framework about 0.5 billion after tax.
So no update there at this point?
1.5 billion to 0.5 billion.
Thanks very much.
Okay, great.
Terry, thanks for your final questions. I'll turn it over to Jeff Immelt for final remarks.

Great, Trevor. Thanks. Again, in a very tough environment, we delivered results that were consistent with what we talked about in December; earned almost $4 billion in the quarter and $18 billion for the year. I think the highlight of the quarter is the strong Industrial cash flow and the really strong strength of the balance sheet, particularly with the cash on hand on the balance sheet. The framework for 2009 we have no change to, and that's what we talked about in December.

And lastly, I just want to go back to a point which I think was part of Scott's question is that we think given the strong operating performance of the company and the framework and the strong capital position that we still believe that supporting the dividend and doing it without straining, doing it just by controlling our own destiny and by executing with excellence. That is the best use of capital and capital allocation. So we run the company to be a AAA. We've supported and have on hand lots of cash and lots of capital. And we're really running the place, controlling our own destiny with real excellence and focus.
So thanks for your attention and Trevor, I turn it back to you.

Great; thanks, Jeff. Just a few closing items for everyone, I appreciate everyone's questions and their time today. A replay will be available this afternoon on our website. Our next earnings call for the first quarter will be held on April 17. And as always, JoAnna and I will be available to take your questions today. Thank you very much for your time.
And this concludes your conference call. Thank you for your participation today. You may now disconnect.
